description.narrative: Core support to icddr,b Bangladesh, Centrum for Diarrhoeal Research based in Dhaka. It is a continuation of earlier support. Duration is 2012-2014 with total 30 MSEK/distr annually with 10 MSEK. The responsibility for the contr lies at Emb/Dhaka in overall coop with PARTNER/FORSK who is resp for addit research support via Regional Asia/resp Sida HQ, 6 million SEK/year 2012-2015, MSEK 24

Insitutionsstöd till icddr,b, Centrum för Dirrhoeal Disease Research i Bangladesh 2012-2014 m 30 MSEK, fördelat på 10 MSEK årligen. Stödet är en fortsättning på tidigare stöd. Ansvar för stödet ligger på amb/Dhaka med övergrip ansvar i samarbete PARTNER/FORSK där det finns ett forskningsstöd på 6 MSEK/år 2012-2016 från regionala Asien, delegerat till PARTNER/FORSK.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Measured against the logic model and Performance Measurement Framework, and subsequent agreed revisions of the balanced scorecard, as well as the annual organizational assessments conducted by the Core Donor Group including Sweden, DfID and Canada, icddr,b has successfully leveraged the core support to make significant contributions to improving the health of the poor globally through improved knowledge. The Swedish core funding has contributed to strengthening icddr,b’s capacity for research, to addressing neglected areas of research, and to assisting young researchers in their career development. Over the programme period, the Swedish support has helped icddr,b to make notable progress in promoting gender equality and in the systematic inclusion of gender considerations in all areas of research. The Swedish support has reaped rewards in generating evidence to inform health policy and practice both in Bangladesh and globally. While the link between research and health outcomes can be difficult to establish, by widely shared consensus Sweden has supported icddr,b in contributing to the following improved health outcomes in Bangladesh: • Continuous reduction in the total fertility rate in Bangladesh through national implementation of a comprehensive approach to promotion and support of family planning; • Child mortality reduced over the last 20 years through the use of vaccines proven effective in icddr,b field trials; • Achieving a 40% decline in maternal mortality in Bangladesh over the last nine years (supported by this programme and previous Swedish core funding); • Achieving the national MDG target for reducing under-five mortality (particularly from infectious diseases).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
